Proposal Title: High-Resolution, Non-Contacting, Active Control Piezoelectric
Small Business Concern_Address: 11506 Gilleland Road, Huntsville, AL Zip:35803
Technical Abstract: Synergistic materials and multifunctional structures fabrication technologies will be developed, evaluated, and intergrated to enhance and enable the design and operation of next generation ultralightweight space telescopes: (1) membrane reflectors comprised of preformed piezoelectric film laminated with preformed seamless polyimide films; (2) preformed piezoelectric polyimide reflector films; (3) active non-contact reflector membrane shape control using an electron gun; and (4) deployable preformed thin polyimide film reflector support structure elements and assemblies that have sufficient inherent stiffness or can be permanently rigidized with lightweight structural foam. All four technologies are scaleable and can provide significant increase in reflector surface accuracy and reduction in cost and weight of large telescope systems.
Potential non-NASA applications: This work can lead to demonstrated practical breakthroughs in large-scale ultralightweight highly accurate thin film reflectors for solar thermal rocket concentrators, large antennas, microwave concentrators, next generation telescopes, and solar conccentrators for electrical power generation and high temperature materials processing in space. The technology is also applicable to smart switches, sensors, and transducers that respond to stimuli such as heat, light or electric and magnetic fields.
Research Institution Address: 201 Kinkead Hall, Lexington, KY Zip:40506-9420

Proposal Title: 100 mJ, 100 Hz Conductively-cooled High Brightness Laser
Small Business Concern_Address: 20 Point West, St. Charles, MO Zip:63301
Technical Abstract: Design and construct a space capable laser transmitter with 100 mJ/pulse, 3-30 ns pulse width, 40 to 100 Hz repetition rate, with 3 pm resolution and >5% overall efficiency.
Potential non-NASA applications: The laser will be of considerable interest to many military and industrial consumers. On the military front, there are numerous tools, such as the Airborne Laser and various lidar programs, that require a laser such as this that has high energy, high brightness, very efficient and small/light-weight. In the industrial sector, a 100 Hz laser is not in as much demand. However, the lessons learned in this effort are directly applicable to the classical industrial laser system. In the medical arena, there are applications for a 100 Hz system, and in this instance, compactness, high brightness are key features. In addition, the lessons learned in this effort should be, at least in part, transferable to very common medical and industrial laser systems which are usually CW pumped.
Research Institution Address: 4400 Massachusetts Ave, NW, Washington, DC Zip:20016-8066

Proposal Title: Light-Weight, High Specific Impulse (1000 sec) Space
Small Business Concern_Address: 25 East Loop Road, Stony Brook, NY Zip:11790-3350
Technical Abstract: Development of affordable, high performance nuclear engines enable a quantum leap in the capability to carry out exploration and commercialization of the solar system, particularly with regard to the more distant planets and moons. Utilization of nuclear engines will result in much shorter trip times and much smaller and cheaper launch vehicles that contribute to dramatic reductions in mission costs. A new ultra-compact nuclear engine concept, MITEE (MIniature reacTor EnginE), is described, and its performance evaluated for various solar system exploration missions. The MITEE concept will serve as a temporary bridge to the development of very advanced and much higher Isp rockets based on nuclear fusion/antimatter which will be required for the exploration and colonization of the solar system. The company plans to apply and extend the knowledge gained from the MITEE project to the systems research and development of fusion/antimatter engines. Representative design parameters for the baseline MITEE reactor are: 75 MW(th) power level, 1000 seconds Isp, 100 kg mass, 10 MW/Liter fuel element power density, 39 cm core diameter/height. Total engine mass, including turbopump, nozzles, controls, and contingency is estimated to be 200 kg. Using the MITEE engine, ultra-fast, lightweight solar system exploration missions are enabled.
Potential non-NASA applications: Satellite and telecommunications manufacturers would have a vested interest in derivative applications of the MITEE engine. Compact heat engines based on this technology would provide electric power in the kilo and megawatt range for satellite operations. Major aerospace companies can benefit from space satellite retrieval/orbit changes from orbital transfer/maneuvering vehicles based on bimodal engine configurations which entail both propulsion and power producing capabilities. In addition, small powerplants can be constructed to provide energy for usage in remote and isolated outposts both on Earth and other celestial bodies. Energy conversion techniques can include static applications as a replacement for radioisotope thermoelectric generators (RTG), or dynamic applications as seen in heat engines utilizing the Brayton or Rankine cycles. In a novel concept, low cost, robust outposts can be established with indigenous resources processed to manufacture breathable air, food and stockpile propellants, fuel, and construction materials. Space mining can be made cost- effective with other MITEE technology derivatives even with the use of today's existing launchers. Another application of this technology centers on designing nuclear engines that enable low-cost distant intercept missions against Near Earth Object impactors that the Earth with catastrophic collisions.
Research Institution Address: College of Engineering & Applied Science, Stony Brook, NY Zip:11794-2300

Proposal Title: Hydrocarbon-Fueled Rocket Engine Health Monitoring by Laser-
Small Business Concern_Address: P. O. Box 22745, Santa Fe, NM Zip:87502-2745
Technical Abstract: An important aspect of rocket engine testing is engine wear. One method that has been used to monitor for rocket engine wear is atomic emission in the UV-visible region from metal species in the plume. An alternative method that offers the promise of increased sensitivity and spatial resolution is laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy. This method uses atomic emission from a micro-plasma formed at the focus of a high peak power laser. It uses gated-detection with a fixed delay after the laser pulse. This has the advantage of discriminating against background emission in the plume. Also the laser micro-plasma has a higher temperature than the plume, which increases atomic emission strength. During Phase I a LIBS system will be developed and demonstrated on several hydrocarbon-fuel flames and test stands. It will be optimized for sensitivity. Its capabilities, including detection limits and spatial resolution, will be characterized and reported. At the end of Phase II a working prototype will be completed and fully tested.
Potential non-NASA applications: In addition to being a monitor for rocket engine wear, the LIBS system can be used to monitor automobile engines for metal species in the exhaust. This would be useful for monitoring engine health as well as monitoring for toxic metals released in the atmosphere as pollutants. A similar application for jet engines is apparent.
Research Institution Address: P. O. Box MM, Mississippi State, MS Zip:39762

Proposal Title: Antimatter Plasma Gun for Advanced Thruster Research
Small Business Concern_Address: 19 Karen Circle, Los Alamos, NM Zip:87544
Technical Abstract: Antiprotons offer the largest specific energy of any material known to mankind, making them extremely attractive as a space propulsion fuel. Several concepts have been proposed over the past decade. An attractive option uses the antiprotons to create a dense hot plasma which, when exhausted from the confining vessel, provides direct thrust. Another option uses the plasma to trigger nuclear microfusion reactions providing the requisite specific impulse and thrust for interplanetary, and even interstellar, missions. Recent progress by G.A. Smith at Penn State University toward the creation of a portable antiproton trap and a recently funded project at MSFC to develop the next generation trap with substantially greater capacity (10^12 antiprotons), now make it possible to design an Antimatter Plasma Gun (APG) derived around the Penning Trap principles. We foresee designing and eventually building a device which can provide a bright, small-emittance ion beam with several eV to KeV energy. This device would enable the aforementioned space propulsion applications to be investigated in a laboratory setting as well as revolutionize many other applications of plasmas which currently depend on large, expensive, and hazardous sources.
Potential non-NASA applications: The potential for commercial applications of the Antimatter Plasma Gun (APG) is great because the APG would provide a compact and inexpensive alternative to the large and expensive sources of dense, hot plasma that exist today. The potential applications include: advanced space propulsion, fusion energy research, plasma surface coating technology, high-power plasma switches, gas discharge lasers, isotope separation, research into magnetohydrodyamic principles for electric power plants and portable power supplies, pollution control and reduction, and materials processing.
Research Institution Address: 303 Osmond Laboratory, University Park, PA Zip:16802

Proposal Title: Unity Power Factor Interface for Data Processing Equipment
Small Business Concern_Address: 200 Technology Way, Butte, MT Zip:59702-4078
Technical Abstract: In the present computer market, premium is placed upon computational performance measures, not on the quality of input current waveform, leading to power factor and power quality problems at computing facilities with no off-the-shelf remedies currently available. Montana State University - Bozeman has developed power conversion technology employing Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) for instanteous control of ac power flow. In the proposed project, PWM ac-ac power conversion technology will be applied to solve power quality problems posed by loads such as data processing and computing equipment. A Unity Power Factor (UPF) interface device, which shapes the supply line current to be sinusoidal, will be developed. The UPF will have an input that connects to the utility outlet and an ouput that supplies power to the computing equipment. The user can plug the UPF interface into a standard wall outlet and plug nonlinear loads such as computers into its outlet. The objective for Phase I of the proposed project is to study the feasibility of the proposed UPF approach for computing equipment. A computer simulation of the proposed UPF interface will be developed and a laboratory breadboard prototype of the interface will be developed to verify the results of the simulations.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed research can have a definite commercial impact with respect to several potential commercial markets such as: (1) a replacement for all switch mode power supplies, (2) as an input power accessory where substantial numbers of PC computer devices are operated, and (3) as an accessory to the ballast component where large numbers of flouresent lighting fixtures are used. A particular advantage that successful UPF development can offer over present practices is in buildings and facilities where large numbers of switching mode power supplies are utilized. This is due to the fact that the original wiring and electrical equipment ratings were often established assuming power factors based upon the phase angle and not the actual power factor determined by the switching function. The actual power factor results in electrical currents in excess of the angle based determination.
Research Institution Address: P. O. Box 172470, Bozeman, MT Zip:59717-2470

Proposal Title: Signal Processing and Classification for Health Monitoring
Small Business Concern_Address: 10001 Derekwood Lane - Suite 204, Lanham, MD Zip:20706
Technical Abstract: The objective of this work is to design new signal processing algorithms for a &quotsmart" eddy current array sensor system that will enable gas turbine blade diagnostics and high cycle fatigue prognosis. The approach uses fast, adaptive wavelet transforms for spatio-temporal mechanical signature analysis to extract diagnostic information from measured signal patterns in real time. The methodology combines computational modeling of the sensor waveform based on physical principles of the sensor operation and data-driven analysis of blade model vibration and stress mode shapes. Preliminary experimental tests show that the sensor and wavelet analysis can detect variations in blade configuration, and can indicate the on-set of engine stall. The work will contribute to the implementation of new on-line high performance health monitoring for turbine engines. It will leverage ongoing development of eddy current sensors with high performance, efficient computational algorithms that support the deployment of sensor arrays. The formulation is general and can be adapted to other types of sensors and other diagnostic and prognostic health monitoring applications.
Potential non-NASA applications: The application potential for an on-board blade health monitoring is tremendous. This work will lead to new sensor technologies and signal processing algorithms for diagnostics and prognostics for high-performance turbine engine systems. It will contribute to new methods of health monitoring for these critical components. The director of Prognostics and Health Management for the Joint Strike Fighter at Pratt & Whitney has already indicated his interest in our preliminary findings. The signal processing technology will be marketed jointly with GD/ATS to prime contractors and engine manufacturers.
Research Institution Address: Math Department, College Park, MD Zip:20742

Proposal Title: SOFT SWITCHING UNITY POWER FACTOR CORRECTION CIRCUITS
Small Business Concern_Address: 409 Eastbridge, Oviedo, FL Zip:32765
Technical Abstract: The proposed project will address two important issues in power quality and power density in non-linear AC/DC power systems. A new power switching technique known as soft-switching will be used to design high-power density systems with improved efficiency while achieving near unity power factor. Unlike the traditional passive approach, the newly developed technology by the University of Central Florida will result in total elimination of line current distortion, resulting in near unity power factor (PF) and low Total Harmonic Distortion (THD). This new soft-switching technique will result in more than 30% reduction in the size of the switching power supplies currently installed at KSC facilities. Different AC/DC power factor topologies will be compared with respect to their efficiency, and power density (size and weight). Also, the application of the new PFC topologies in the design of Distributed Power Systems (DPS) along with their cost and control complexity will be investigated.
Potential non-NASA applications: Users of computer systems and other control systems that use AC/DC power supplies stand to gain the most due to energy cost and system performance. Other potential applications include vehicle technology, space communication systems, phased-radar arrays and satellites. Furthermore, the proposed DPS control scheme is an essential system for the design of high performance, high power density systems used extensively in commercial and military applications.
Research Institution Address: Electrical and Computer Engineering, Orlando, FL Zip:32816

Proposal Title: Lightweight Optics in Vanasil (LOV)
Small Business Concern_Address: 2702 Triana Blvd, STE A, Huntsville, AL Zip:35805
Technical Abstract: Vanasil, a metal matrix composite, has: 3 times the microyield to weight ratio of beryllium; 10 times the thermal conductivity of silicon carbide; homogeneous optical surfaces, no moisture sensitivity, nor thermal cycling problems, unlike graphite epoxy; thermal expansion which matches optical platings and coatings; non-hazardous, non-toxic, unlike beryllium; and fabrication technology which allows optimum lightweight structures. Vanasil can be formed into complex shapes by casting, and is low cost. Our Phase I STTR program will explore Vanasil optics by fabricating hardware test items; an optical substrate with a ribbing structure will be cast, and a brazing process will be developed using vanasil coupons.
Potential non-NASA applications: A new option for ultra lightweight optics with a unique set of properties will provide NASA will a wider range of choices. This option is potentially the lightest weight of any known approaches. The low cost, easily manufactured structures have commercial potential for simple and complex optical metering structures.
Research Institution Address: Bearcreek Road, Y12 Plant, Oak Ridge, TN Zip:37831-8039

Proposal Title: High Accuracy Modular Thrust Measurement System Utilizing
Small Business Concern_Address: 460 Falke Ct., Anchorage, AK Zip:99504-1064
Technical Abstract: A magnetic bearing test fixture is an ideal candidate for NASA's current and future requirements for thrust measurement. Magnetic bearings (MB) are a proven technology in large commercial applications such as centrifugal compressors and turbo-expanders and they are being utilized as load cells in laboratory environments. The major drawback to using MB as thrust measurements devices is the complex calibration procedure. This project will result in more accurate actuators and a greatly simplified calibration procedure. Technology currently being developed at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (VT) will allow the utilization of active magnetic bearings (MB) as highly accurate force measurement systems with on-line calibration characteristics. In the proposed project, Imlach Consulting Engineering (ICE) will work with VT to develop, design, and analyze a thrust measurement system utilizing a modular system of highly efficient and accurate magnetic bearing actuators and the on-line calibration technology. The resulting thrust measurement system for rocket engine testing will to offer greater flexibility and adaptability to changing test requirements, while reducing changeover time and operating costs. The project will also develop and experimentally verify improved MB design tools which will be incorporated into advanced computational design tools for magnetic bearing (MB) actuators.
Potential non-NASA applications: Three commercial applications will be developed from this project. First, the design of the test rig will be of interest to companies requiring measurement of large axial loads generated by fluid forces (engines, compressors, turbines, etc.). Secondly, the on-line calibration procedure will be developed into a stand alone code that can be used with the digital controller of any MB system to measure in-situ bearing loads. This technology will be marketed to MB users and vendors for use in machinery and process controls and diagnostics. Finally, the improved MB design tools developed in this project will be marketed to MB users and vendors to improve the accuracy and usabiltiy of MB systems.
Research Institution Address: 301 Burruss Hall, Blacksburg, VA Zip:24061-0238

Proposal Title: High sensitivity Nitride based UV Detectors
Small Business Concern_Address: 2925 College Avenue, Unit A-01, Costa Mesa, CA Zip:92626
Technical Abstract: Avyd Devices, Inc. and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute propose an approach which combines the advantages of the capability to grow high crystalline quality epitaxial layers of GaN and GaAlN via the metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) technique with a p type doping approach which could result in much higher conductivity p type GaN and GaAlN layers and hence much improved p type contact resistance and quantum efficiency along with a much sharper UV spectral response facilitating efficient rejection of the longer wavelength radiation. Phase I emphasis will be focused on demonstrating the feasibility to develop a nitride based p-i-n UV detector technology capable of providing detectors with high responsivity, low noise and high speed. In phase I we plan to demonstrate and deliver to NASA single element and linear arrays of p-i-n photodetectors of GaN . In phase II, we plan to demonstrate and deliver 256x256 imaging arrays of these devices.
Potential non-NASA applications: environmental monitoring, automobile engine combustion sensing, remote sensing of earth resources, solar astronomy, burner monitoring in gas turbines etc.
Research Institution Address: 110 Eigth Street, Troy, NY Zip:12180

Proposal Title: Advanced Magnetostrictive Composite Materials and Devices
Small Business Concern_Address: 2500 North Loop Drive, Ames, IA Zip:50010
Technical Abstract: ETREMA Products, Inc. and the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) will develop and commercialize new smart material and device products for use in advanced spacecraft and aircraft in order to reduce production and operating costs. Work done at UCLA in the development of magnetostrictive composite materials using epoxies will be extended and transferred to industry. The production of these new smart materials will enable low cost devices that surpass the limitations of current composite material technologies based on epoxies or typical polyimides, including limited service temperature, low fracture toughness, material instability and hydrolysis. The advanced magnetostrictive composite materials and devices are enabled by combining two novel material classes: advanced resin systems and magnetostrictive smart materials. These advanced composite materials will provide a high performance smart material with structural capabilities, excellent durability and high temperature capability, while overcoming the electrical connectivity problems associated with piezoceramic composites. With the commercialization of TERFENOL- D alloys, and devices and systems based thereon, ETREMA has proven it is successful in materials technology transfer. It can be equally successful in the development of low-cost production methods and products based on improved smart materials and transducers (actuators, sensors, etc.).
Potential non-NASA applications: The list of potential products (including those requiring cryogenic performance), which will be made possible by this material development, can be broken down into several categories which include: actuators of all types, pumps, valves, active flow control systems, vibration dampers, structural health monitoring systems, scanner motors, MEMS, thin films, sensors, etc. By taking advantage of the broad thermal capabilities of the novel constituent materials, these products can be designed for use in temperatures ranging from cryogenics (such as NASA's NGST satellite) to over 200Ã¸C. Actuators will find use in mirror and other optics positioning, deployment of structures, powering remote vehicle manipulators, locking and latching mechanisms for docking, and other very low frequency applications, or applications which require a position and hold capability with high stiffness. Medium frequency applications will include pumps, valves, and both active and passive structural vibration dampers. High frequency applications could include such things as instrument scanner motors and even the possibility of generating ultrasonic acoustic streaming for moving liquids without pressure buildup and heating.
Research Institution Address: 38-137 Engineering IV P.O. Box 951597, Los Angeles, CA Zip:90095-1597

Proposal Title: ROBUST EXHAUST GAS SENSING SYSTEM USING ADVANCED THIN FILM
Small Business Concern_Address: 1020 Marauder Street, Suite D, Chico, CA Zip:95973-9001
Technical Abstract: Makel Engineering, Inc. (MEI) and Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) propose to develop a compact, rugged, low cost, quantitative sensor for measurement of multiple species in the exhaust of turbine driven aircraft. The multi-species exhaust sensor (MSES) will provide quantitative measurement of NOx, O2, CO and hydrocarbons in air breathing propulsion exhaust. The system is based on the use of high temperature, thin film sensors, using silicon and silicon carbide manufacturing processes developed at CWRU. These sensors are combined with compact, micro-electronic control circuits. This system will provide real-time data suitable for engine emissions control. The sensor system will be suitable for harsh flight conditions. The gas specific sensor elements will be integrated into a miniature sensor head which will be suitable for integration into a vehicle control system. The proposed sensor system will provide: (1) real-time quantitative measurement of key exhaust species, (2) lightweight, robust module, (3) digital communications immune to EMI and RFI, and (4) built-in-test (BIT) and health monitoring capability. Phase I will focus on the integration of NOx and O2 sensors and Phase II will expand the capability for CO and hydrocarbon detection.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed MEEMS is directly applicable to commercial aircraft, diesel engine, and gas turbine industries. Significant rapid commercialization of this system is expected because of (1) the growing importance of NOx measurements and control on mobile and stationary power sources, (2) the potential of the technology to produce a low cost device, and (3) flexibility of the system design to use interchangeable sensors for different gases.
Research Institution Address: Electronic Design Center, Bingham Bldg., Cleveland, OH Zip:44106

Proposal Title: Controlled Isolation of Science Instrumentation Packages
Small Business Concern_Address: 1700 Riverside Dr., So. Willilamsport, PA Zip:17701
Technical Abstract: Significant research and development is underway for NGST and SIM regarding steady state wavefront error correction. However, little appears to have been developed in regard to dynamic wavefront error correction. Yet, the issue of minimizing dynamic error correction requirements by eliminating on-axis accelerations and off-axis accelerations is of crucial importance to NGST, SIM and other astrophysics missions. Introducing controlled isolation will minimize on-axis accelerations and off-axis accelerations (via electronic differential control) by integrating smart materials and advanced electronics design. This new concept is multifunctional since it serves to effectively isolate the space bus and the scientifc instrumentation module and simultaneously acts to implement pointing axis correction for the entire OTA assembly as to reduce the fine error correction requirements burden on the active optics.
Potential non-NASA applications: The results of this research are important for 'real world' military and commercial applications. EMF is exploring with TRW Civil & International Division, Harris Corporation Mililtary and Space Division and Boeing ISDS, the introduction of a practical compact, lightweight isolation system to a wide range of launch system and astrophysics platform applications. The technology has direct migration to automotive systems, machinery mounts and isolation tables.
Research Institution Address: 233 Hammond Building, University Park, PA Zip:16802

Proposal Title: A Novel Design and Fabrication Process for Optical Filters for
Small Business Concern_Address: 175 Clearbrook Rd., Elmsford, NY Zip:10523
Technical Abstract: HYPRES proposes the development of a versatile design and manufacturing process for long-wavelength optical filters. The technology will produce bandpass filters with any desired center wavelength between 20 microns and 10 mm, using silicon substrates and one standard set of materials and thicknesses. With the aid of a computer program, it will be possible to design filters with specified optical characteristics, and know that the first ones produced will accurately match the specifications. This is a significant advance over existing filter production methods which require different materials for different parts of the spectrum, and cannot, in many cases, achieve desired optical specifications without at least one trial run. The proposed manufacturing process will be capable of producing bandpass filters, notch filters, beamsplitters and polarizers. These components will find application in astronomy from balloons, satellites and SOFIA (Stratospheric Observatory for Airborne Astronomy). In Phase I HYPRES will manufacture bandpass filters with center wavelengths in the range of 0.3 mm to 10 mm, measure their characteristics, and compare them to a computer model. By the end of Phase I, it will be possible to produce low-cost bandpass filters with any specified center frequency in that range.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed bandpass filters will find application in a number of astro- nomical instruments and missions. They will also be used for air pollution measurement and climate monitoring, where the filters will improve the signal- to-noise ratio of submillimeter mixer measurements of trace gases. Interferometers for far-infrared spectroscopy of crystals and plastics are an application for beam splitters, which can also be produced by the proposed fabrication technology.
Research Institution Address: 5460 S. Ellis Ave., Chicago, IL Zip:60637

Proposal Title: Clean Process Catalysts for Removal of Ammonia and Organic
Small Business Concern_Address: 12838 W. Adriatic Ave., Lakewood, CO Zip:80228
Technical Abstract: Advanced catalysts with high efficiency and improved physical properties are projected as valuable tools for both spacecraft life support systems and industrial processes. It is well documented that reductions in expendable resources are required for cost-effective presence of man in space. Catalytic oxidation to remove contaminants in air and water is a key unit operation available to achieve this. These processes use fixed bed reactors consisting of supported noble metal catalysts. The two most widely used supports are alumina and activated carbon. According to extensive research by both NASA and industry, an order of magnitude more efficiency is obtained by using carbon versus alumina. Carbon-supported catalysts are susceptible to long-term physical degradation (due to shear forces and metal leaching) and chemical degradation (by oxidation of solid carbon to CO2) under reactor conditions. Materials with markedly improved physical stability, increased temperature range, and high catalytic activity are proposed. Phase I will investigate treatments to improve the operating temperature range and adherence of the catalytic metal to the carbon surface. Screening tests will be performed to assess suitability of new materials for both space and industrial process conditions. Phase II will consist of full development and long-term testing resulting in materials for dual-use.
Potential non-NASA applications: This technology, if successfully developed, has been identified by a major industrial catalyst company as having potential for immediate product sales of 6,000-20,000 lbs catalyst/month (with product sales over 1.5 million dollars/month) for &quotclean" chemical processing and environmental technology. An additional five industrial processes, each with product sales over 100 million dollars/year have been documented that would also be likely markets for the proposed product. All of these projections are documented.
Research Institution Address: Attn: Dr. Scott Cowley, Golden, CO Zip:80401

Proposal Title: Weakly Ionized Shock Wave Modification System
Small Business Concern_Address: 7001 Shallowford Road, Chattanooga, TNZip:37421
Technical Abstract: Accurate Automation and Old Dominion University propose to develop a weakly ionized gas shock wave modification system for an advanced rocket or reusable launch vehicle. We will develop a theoretical model for the WIG shock wave modification technology, initiate an experimental program to support the ongoing theoretical work, evaluate the engineering feasibility of employing the technology on an operational rocket or reusable launch vehicle, and perform a conceptual design for a wind tunnel test article. This Phase I program will lay the foundations for a Phase II program in which the WIG shock wave modification technology will be demonstrated in a wind tunnel and a detailed engineering feasibility study for an operational vehicle will be performed.
Potential non-NASA applications: In the near term we anticipate that the Phase III customers for the proposed program will be NASA, DoD, and/or their prime contractors, while commercialization of the technology in the civil aviation industry may result from the success of the NASA and DoD Phase III programs. Specific programs that we have targeted include: * NASA's advanced rocket and reusable launch vehicle programs * Navy's hypersonic weapons programs * NASA's hypersonic research aircraft programs * The JSF and other DoD subsonic and supersonic aircraft programs * The Air Force's Fixed Wing Vehicle Program * Advanced civil aircraft programs
Research Institution Address: 800 West 46th Street, Norfolk, VAZip:23508-0369

Proposal Title: Inductive Magnetized Plasma Accelerator for Deep Space
Small Business Concern_Address: 16436 SE 39th Place, Bellevue, WA Zip:98008
Technical Abstract: It is recognized that nuclear fusion is the only known source that can provide the prodigious amounts of power required for deep space missions. This is due to both the large and available quantities of fuel. Of all fusion reactor embodiments, only the magnetically confined plasma in the Field Reversed Configuration (FRC) has the ideal linear geometry, the low confining field and high plasma pressure required for the direct conversion of fusion energy into high specific impulse and thrust. The FRC has demonstrated in experiments the scaling with size and density required for fusion ignition. Due to the high plasma pressure and compactness of the magnetic configuration, there has been no easy way to extrapolate the FRC into the reactor regime. Based on experiment, a simple way has been determined by which the FRC can be readily brought to ignition conditions. This state is achieved by employing an Inductive, Magnetized Plasma Accelerator (IMPAC). It is the intention of MSNW to design (Phase I), and construct (Phase II) the prototype IMPAC source. The source alone, when externally powered, could produce the thrust and Isp necessary for a fast Mars mission in a device smaller than a desk.
Potential non-NASA applications: A successful outcome of the IMPAC based fusion rocket would of course, at the very least, allow man to explore and colonize the planets, and possibly extend man's reach to other worlds beyond our solar system. Certainly NASA would be a customer, as no doubt any other organization, governmental or not, that value this same vision for mankind. In the short term, the IMPAC source would provide a small, extremely efficient, propulsion device at very low cost, and development time. The IMPAC source would provide more than enough Isp and thrust to accomplish rapid space travel to nearby planets, and would make possible the commercial use of space beyond the earth. Perhaps though, the major spin-off of this power source, a terrestrially based fusion reactor, would have the most significant commercial application. The customer in this case would essentially be the entire world, as fusion represents the only long term, non-polluting, energy source that could supply the earth's energy needs.
Research Institution Address: Redmond Plasma Physics Lab 14700 NE 95th, Redmond, WA Zip:98052

Proposal Title: Dynamical Position Estimation in Self-Sensing Magnetic
Small Business Concern_Address: 1160 Pepsi Place, Suite 300, Charlottesville, VA Zip:22901
Technical Abstract: Magnetic bearings represent an important candidate technology for aerospace applications. They offer improved efficiency (through complete elimination of friction) and reliability (from reduced wear) over conventional bearings. Commercial development, however, has been impeded largely by cost considerations, chiefly those accruing to rotor displacement sensors. Self- sensing technology, wherein rotor displacement is inferred through the information content of the amplifier current signals, is now a widely accepted paradigm that allows rotor position sensors to be eliminated. In past SBIR work for NASA, Barron Associates, Inc. developed a polynomial neural network self- sensing solution that covers the magnetic non- saturation and saturation regimes, the latter where the relationship between rotor displacement and bearing currents is highly nonlinear. The proposed Phase I STTR research will focus on extending this neural network approach to dynamic scenarios, in which rotor position and actuation currents are time-varying. Dynamic scenarios are important for practical usage of the technique. The Phase II sequel will bring this technology to fruition in the form of a laboratory spinning rig demonstration of the self-sensing technology operating in the saturation regime.
Potential non-NASA applications: Commercial applications of magnetic bearings include a host of aeronautic and niche industrial applications, such as aircraft engine and power systems, rotating machinery, flywheels, kinetic compressors, and heart pumps. Self- sensing will play a decisive role in making magnetic bearing technology cost effective and sufficiently reliable. Embedded polynomial neural network algorithms for self-sensing in integrated power units (IPUs) for aircraft power systems and in high-speed pumps for the petrochemical industry are the two commercial applications on which the STTR work will focus in collaboration with Sundstrand Aerospace, the Barron Associates, Inc. commercialization sponsor.
Research Institution Name: University of Virginia, School of Eng'g
Research Institution Address: Thornton Hall, McCormick Road, Charlottesville, VA Zip:22903

Proposal Title: Extendable technology for ultra-stable lasers at 630.5 nm and
Small Business Concern_Address: 2630 Walsh Avenue, Santa Clara, CA Zip:95051-0905
Technical Abstract: We propose to produce a compact stabilized tunable diode laser system emitting 630.5 nm light with frequency drift reduced to less than one part per billion over periods longer than 10 hours. A novel atomic-reference-free stabilization scheme developed by Dr. John Hall adapted for external cavity diode lasers engineered at Focused Research will provide absolute frequency calibration. Uniquely, this system will stabilize any wavelength selected within the laser's tuning range, enabling new scientific and industrial applications. The method is applicable to existing visible and infrared wavelengths and we can satisfy NASA's needs for ultrastable lasers at shorter wavelengths as new laser diodes become available.
Potential non-NASA applications: Commercial opportunities for economical, robust, and tunable wavelength- stabilized lasers include industry applications such as telecommunications test equipment, high-resolution interferometry, and micropositioning, surface defect inspection, and low-power LIDAR (laser radar). The proposed system would be especially well suited to a variety of spectroscopic applications in the scientific and engineering communities as well. Dr. Hall is renowned for pioneering high-performance laser frequency locking techniques. Focused Research and its parent company, New Focus, is a technology leader in tunable external cavity diode lasers ideally suited to frequency locking. Combining our expertise in laser design and stabilization methods, we will achieve the low cost and high performance necessary for the industrial stabilized laser market.
Research Institution Address: 325 Broadway, Boulder, CO Zip:80303-3328

Proposal Title: Polyimide Spray-Foaming Process
Small Business Concern_Address: 1850 Four Mile Vue Road, Butte, MT Zip:59701
Technical Abstract: A thermal method for directly applying LaRC-IA polyimide as a high-quality spray-foam as an insulation onto a substrate, such as fuel or cryogenic liquid tanks, will be developed and demonstrated. The proposed technology will lower the costs of using polyimide foams by providing a method of applying specialty, advanced lightweight, polyimide foams to directly onto complex shapes and structures. The project shall include the spraying of NASA's newly invented LaRC-IA polyimide shapes to form an adherent, mechanically-sound, insulating foam. The resulting advanced polyimide foams will be lighter and can be used for higher temperature applications than existing polymer sprayable foams. The novel thermal spray method will convey, heat and deposit the advanced LaRC- IA polyimide materials onto substrates. A key aspect of the Phase I work includes the development of polyimide bonding methods that are compatible with the novel thermal spray technology. Phase I will establish feasibility of the process and be used to evaluate three different polyimide material bonding methods. Phase II work will demonstrate the operation and control of a prototype process suitable for spraying polyimide foams onto a functioning substrate, such as a fuel or cryogenic liquid tank.
Potential non-NASA applications: The proposed project will promote the use of newly developed polyimide materials as high-temperature insulation on NASA, military and commerical spacecraft, such as the space shuttle, the X-33 and future Reusable Launch Vehicles (RLV). Applications for quothigh-performance" foams, such as the polyimide foams proposed herein, particularly sprayable foams, currently exist in aerospace, marine, aircraft, automotive, recreational and electronics markets.
Research Institution Address: CSU, CSU/PO Box3355, Fort Collins/Laramie WY 82071, CO Zip:80523

Proposal Title: Lightweight Thruster for Laser-Assisted Propulsion
Small Business Concern_Address: 6888 Nancy Ridge Drive, San Diego, CA Zip:92121-2232
Technical Abstract: Small &quotLightcraft" thrusters have recently been propelled from ground level to 30-m altitude on laser power beamed from a terrestrial source. Such technology represents a clean and potentially low-cost access to space for small payloads. This STTR project further develops the materials technology in a collaboration between Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI), the Research Organization that originated the Lightcraft propulsion concept, and Energy Science Laboratories, Inc. (ESLI) a Small Business developing lightweight refractory rocket materials and structures. Phase 1 will design, fabricate and test small-scale air-breathing thrusters made with novel high-temperature lightweight materials. The design is based on experimental aluminum lightcraft developed at RPI. Lightweight refractory components will be fabricated using novel carbon and silicon carbide materials under development at ESLI. A series of small-scale thrusters will be fabricated for use at 10-kW beam power. Flight testing will be used to investigate the effectiveness of materials and design innovations. Phase 2 would further develop materials and structures for laser- assisted propulsion thruster prototypes to achieve higher altitude flight. Preliminary materials design for a 100-kg payload Lightcraft will be drafted for use with higher power lasers.
Potential non-NASA applications: Successful Lightcraft may be used to deliver small payloads to space. The novel materials and structures have potential application where light weight, stiffness, and high temperature capability is required, including rockets, laser mirrors, turbine housings and cooled composite structures.
Research Institution Address: 110 8th St., Troy, NY Zip:12180

Proposal Title: High Temperature Microfabricated Sensors for Aircraft Gas
Small Business Concern_Address: 350 Second Avenue, Waltham, MA Zip:02154-1196
Technical Abstract: Foster-Miller and Cornell University propose to develop very small, low cost sensors for use in aircraft gas turbine engines at temperatures up to 600 oC using microfabrication of silicon nitride based mechanical devices. The results of Phase I will show the feasibility of a high temperature vibration sensor, including building and testing prototype sensors at temperatures from room temperature to 600oC. The data should verify that the new sensors will be useful for sensing and control systems on gas turbine test cells and in service applications for engine health monitoring and autonomous control. Phase II will involve placement of sensors in operating gas turbines, and will show feasibility sensors based on optical fiber interconnection.
Potential non-NASA applications: There is an urgent need for the sensors and control systems in commercial aircraft gas turbines, and in other turbine applications for shipboard power and electric power generation. The annual worldwide market for such sensors and control systems is estimated to be in the hundreds of millions of dollars. The high temperature microfabricated sensors will also find uses in automotive and truck engines, and for heavy industries including steel, chemicals, and other raw material processing.
Research Institution Address: 120 Day Hall, Ithaca, NY Zip:14853

Proposal Title: Space-Qualified Optical Components for Solar Plant Lighting
Small Business Concern_Address: 20 New England Business Center, Andover, MA Zip:01810
Technical Abstract: Physical Sciences Inc. (PSI), in collaboration with the Y-Division (Laser Division) of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL), proposes to develop space-qualified optical components that are building blocks of the Optical Waveguide (OW) solar plant lighting system. In the OW system, solar radiation is collected by the concentrator which transfers the concentrated solar radiation to the OW transmission line consisting of low-loss optical fibers. The OW line transmits the plant lighting spectra (< 700 nm) to the plant growth chamber where the solar radiation from the optical fibers is de-focused for optimum intensity for plant growing. The non-plant growing spectra (> 700 nm) is utilized for generating electric power which will provide plant lighting when solar radiation is not available. PSI has been developing the OW technology in the past few years. Technologies resident at LLNL that are pertinent to the proposed research program include: optics and material technologies for laser power transmission; large diameter optical fiber technologies for continuous wave (CW) power transmission; thermal effects on materials and structure; vacuum technology; and space environment effects. The two technologies resident at LLNL and PSI can be effectively combined for development of the space- qualified optical components for solar plant lighting system.
Potential non-NASA applications: The Optical Waveguide (OW) solar plant lighting technology is well adapted for growing plants in a remote location or in an enclosed chamber using solar irradiance. The proposed program aims at developing space-qualified optical components for utilization of solar energy in space. In any commercial application areas, whether energy, telecommunication, transportation, or agriculture, innovative concept must be substantiated by enabling component technologies. The space-qualified optical components for solar plant lighting, when developed to technical maturity, will find applications beyond the plant lighting. They will enable more complete utilization of solar energy not only in space but also in many terrestrial applications. Commercial applications of the solar plant lighting system include the use of the system for energy-efficient crop growing in the polar region, with the state of Alaska as a case in point. The government of Alaska is very interested in employing technologies that are designed to harness natural sunlight for growing plants in closed environments. Another important application of the technology is for indoor lighting in highly crowded cities wherein numerous buildings do not receive any solar irradiance.
Research Institution Address: P.O. Box 808, 7000 East Avenue, Livermore, CA Zip:94550

Proposal Title: Rapid Prototyping and Manufacturing with Ultrasonic Tape
Small Business Concern_Address: 350 Second Avenue, Waltham, MA Zip:02154-1196
Technical Abstract: Foster-Miller has developed an advanced processing technique for organic matrix composites called Ultrasonic Tape Lamination (UTL). This technique employs commercially available ultrasonic welding horns to insonify composite tape (either thermoplastic or B-staged thermoset) to induce controlled and virtually instantaneous viscoelastic and frictional heating in the composites. In this Phase I STTR Foster-Miller will team with Georgia Tech, to extend the technology of Laminated Object Manufacturing (LOM) rapid prototyping with the adaptation/development of UTL. The combination of these two technologies will produce a rapid, controllable and precise composite manufacturing process that will push rapid prototyping into the realm of rapid manufacturing.
Potential non-NASA applications: Once successful UTLOM has been demonstrated with the Phase I program, a Phase II program will design, develop and build a prototype UTLOM machine that will be delivered to NASA. A successful UTLOM machine will be of great interest to the rapid prototyping community, and can be used to fulfill NASA mission requirements with the rapid and inexpensive manufacture of tooling for composite structures. Another application of UTLOM technology will be in tow-placement. UTLOM processing can be readily adapted to automated tow placement equipment allowing out-of-autoclave processing of large composite structures.
Research Institution Address: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Atlanta, GA Zip:30332-0405

Proposal Title: HIGH EFFICIENCY, INTEGRATED MANUFACTURING SYSTEM FOR MARS
Small Business Concern_Address: 1020 Marauder Street, Suite D, Chico, CA Zip:95973-9001
Technical Abstract: Our program is based on these premises: (1) Candidate processes for production of individual products on Mars and the Moon, e.g., oxygen for life support and propulsion, silane for manufacture of silicon chips for solar-electric power generation and propulsion, and ceramics/metals for structures, helium 3 for electric power generation (fusion), hydrogen for propulsion, and water for life support, share common processes; (2) silicon and silicon carbide based microchannel and MEMS (Micro-Electro Mechanical Systems) technology can produce highly efficient components to conduct critical ISRU processes such as electrolysis of water to form hydrogen and oxygen and the reduction of carbon oxides to form useful products, such as propellants, structural materials, and foodstuffs; and (3) near term ISRU demonstration experiments will greatly benefit from ultra-lightweight, compact, integrated chemical processing systems which can be produced using microchannel technology. Specific Phase I program objectives are to design and fabricate silicon microchannel components and to perform bench scale demonstration of ISRU processes important for use on Mars and the Moon. Phase II will develop an engineering prototype system integrating components for quotend-to-end" production of valuable products, such as propellant, for sample return and manned Mars missions.
Potential non-NASA applications: MEMS and microchannel technology is an emerging field with applications in most industrial processes due to excellent mixing, controlled reaction environment, and energy efficiency. This technology offers improvements in existing processes and will enable new processes to become cost effective. Of particular interest is the petrochemical industry for which products from conversion of carbon oxides to stable, useful compounds such as methane and ethylene is of major importance.
Research Institution Address: Electronic Design Center, Bingham Bldg., Cleveland, OH Zip:44106
